meanings.definition: To grant citizenship to someone born in a foreign country.
meanings.sent1: The government decided to naturalise the immigrant after many years of living in the country.
meanings.sent2: The process to naturalise a foreigner can involve various legal steps.
meanings.sent3: The comedy show joked about how long it takes to naturalise someone from another land.
meanings.sent4: Her kindness and warmth naturalised the newcomer into the community seamlessly.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's welcoming attitude helped to naturalise the new student into the class.

meanings.definition: To adapt to a new environment or situation.
meanings.sent1: The plants had to naturalise to the different soil conditions in the garden.
meanings.sent2: It can take time for individuals to naturalise to a different climate.
meanings.sent3: The adventurous explorer had to quickly naturalise to the harsh conditions of the jungle.
meanings.sent4: She had to naturalise to the fast-paced city life after moving from a small town.
meanings.sent5: The athlete needed to naturalise to the high altitude for the upcoming competition.

meanings.definition: To make something appear natural or normal.
meanings.sent1: The artist used lighting to naturalise the colors in the painting.
meanings.sent2: Good acting can naturalise even the most unbelievable scenes in a movie.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to naturalise the disappearance of the rabbit.
meanings.sent4: The designer's goal was to naturalise the flow of the dress on the runway.
meanings.sent5: The chef's presentation skills helped to naturalise the exotic dish to the diners.
